comments.text:
Created attachment 543585
screenshot of the file attachment button on Bugzilla

On RTL Firefox builds, we change the UI direction, and this affects every string including strings rendered inside the browser content area. 

The file input widget has a button with the label "Browse…", which is rendered as "…Browse" if the content area is LTR. An example of this behavior happens in sites such as Bugzilla when the user is using RTL build of its browser. 

Expected result:
Button should be always "Browse…", no matter what is the browser UI. We can fix it by changing the label to "Browse…[RLM]" on each RTL language, or solve it in the core itself.

comments.raw_text:
Presumably the problem's only showing up for file upload because the other auto-generate strings we have (Submit, Reset) don't include any leading/trailing punctuation.

Possible solutions:
  1. Use ‏ after ... in RTL locales, ‎ in LTR locales.
  2. Apply dir=[ltr|rtl] to the button as appropriate for the locale.
  3. Make the button dir=auto once we support that

#1 seems like the simplest answer to me. Are there other places we insert chrome-generated strings into arbitrary content?

Note that editing the text node content in the en-US locale will make us fail HTML5 compliance tests, so if we want bidi controls there in all locales (in case en-US browser is used to browser RTL content), we'll need to change the spec. <isindex> is legacy, though, so it's probably not worthwhile to fix it, since legacy pages wouldn't have been authored in a way that looks wrong in browsers.
